docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers who tracked the eating habits of more than 42,000 men over a 12-year period say they have found proof that a diet they characterize as Western substantially increases the chances of developing diabetes. The researchers, from the Harvard School of Public Health, said diets high in red meat, processed meat, high-fat dairy products, refined grains and desserts increased the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes. Writing in the current Annals of Internal Medicine, they said the risk was worse if the men were also sedentary.

headline.main: New Findings on Diabetes and the Diet

docs.abstract: Harvard School of Public Health researchers, in study published in current Annals of Internal Medicine, find proof that Western diet, high in red meat, processed meat, high-fat dairy products, refined grains and desserts, increases chances of developing diabetes; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People ages 60 to 75 who get flu shots may also be reducing their risk of strokes, researchers have found. A team of French scientists, writing in the current issue of Stroke, an American Heart Association journal, said that among the people they had studied, those who were vaccinated reduced their risk of stroke by about 40 percent.

headline.main: Flu Shots May Reduce Risk of Stroke

docs.abstract: French scientists in study published in currrent issue of American Heart Assn journal Stroke, conclude that people between 60 and 75 years old who get flu shots may reduce risk of strokes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Shaking Up Parkinson Disease,'' by Dr. Abraham Lieberman, Jones & Bartlett Publishers, $18.95. The opening to this instructive book captures the slowly progressive affliction of Parkinson's disease, which has been called ''a disease of moving'' and which also affects emotions, thinking and communicating.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Shaking Up Parkinson Disease by Dr Abraham Lieberman; photo (Books on Health column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that anyone who really wants to become fit can do so. Just walk or ride a bicycle, swim or run. Speed and endurance will improve and what was once hard will become easy. Lift weights, work with a trainer in a gym, and muscles will grow larger and stronger. But when a few intrepid scientists began asking if those beliefs were true, they found that fitness, like weight loss, has genetic underpinnings, making it inherently much easier for some to get fit than it is for others. And the facets of fitness are independent, so those who inherit an ability to gain muscle strength may not be able to grow large muscles and those who can easily increase their ability to do aerobic exercise may be thwarted on the weight room floor.

headline.main: Why Some People Won't Be Fit Despite Exercise

docs.abstract: Article on research conducted by Dr Claude Bouchard and others that strongly suggests that genes determine person's ability at athletic training and ability to build muscles and gain strength; Bouchard is directing national study at five universities to search for genes involved in training effect; study conducted by cardiologist Paul Thompson and geneticist Eric Hoffman concludes that muscle strength and size are not related; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Chain saws, pneumatic drills . . . and PlayStations? A group of doctors in England is warning that all three, under certain conditions, may cause a painful and even disabling condition known as hand-arm vibration syndrome. In a letter published in a recent British Medical Journal, the doctors describe the case of a boy, 15, who had suffered from hand pain for two years. His hands, the doctors wrote, became white and swollen when cold and then red and painful when warmed up again.
docs.abstract: Group of doctors in England, in letter published in British Medical Journal, warn that hours of use of Sony PlayStation video game vibrating hand-held controller may cause painful and disabling condition known as hand-arm vibration syndrome (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Women Are Not Small Men,'' by Dr. Nieca Goldberg, Ballantine Books, $24. When the author of this revealing and helpful book was in medical school, she discovered to her chagrin that all medical care was based on what was normal for a 165-pound man, and that heart disease in women was ''vastly underdiagnosed and poorly treated.''

headline.main: Closing the Gap on Heart Risk for Women

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Women Are Not Small Men by Dr Nieca Goldberg, about impact of heart attacks on women; photo (Books on Health column) (M)

headline.main: Floss Burn, Wallet Burn And Gore

docs.lead_paragraph: The diet police may get after me for saying this, but last-minute shoppers for Valentine's Day (or for any occasion, for that matter) might consider chocolate -- that dark, sweet, melt-in-your-mouth treat that, while not exactly a love potion, is almost universally loved and is not the health disaster that many people assume it to be. In fact, nutritionally speaking, you could do a lot worse. Recent evidence suggests that chocolate -- especially expensive dark chocolate -- is replete with substances that may actually enhance well-being as well as improve one's mood. After all, chocolate does come from the seed of the Theobroma tree, and theobroma is Greek for ''food of the gods.''

headline.main: Valentine to Dark Chocolate, but Go Easy

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on nutritional and health value of chocolate, particularly expensive dark chocolate; notes chocolate is rich in antioxidant flavinoids, can stimulate mind and may delay some ravages of aging; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have long known that there is a link between serious depression and the ability to ward off diseases. But a new study suggests that even mild depression can weaken the immune system in older people if it goes on long enough.
docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers, in study published in Journal of Abnormal Psychology, find link between longterm mild depression and weakening of immune system in older people; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Scientists have long known that there is a link between serious depression and the ability to ward off diseases.    But a new study suggests that even mild depression can weaken the immune system in older people if it goes on long enough.

docs.lead_paragraph: Babies who gain weight too quickly in their first four months appear prone to being overweight later in childhood, a new study reports. The researchers, led by Dr. Nicolas Stettler of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and the University of Pennsylvania, found that how quickly children gained weight early in life was a a better predictor of how heavy they would be at age 7 than other measures, including their weight at birth or at age 1. For each extra 100 grams (about 3.5ounces) they put on in a month, the risk of being overweight later increased by about 30 percent.

headline.main: Early Signs of Problems With Weight

docs.abstract: Researchers at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and University of Pennsylvania conclude tha babies who gain weight too quickly in first four months appear prone to being overweight later in childhood; drawing (M)
